Today is Global Suicide Prevention Day and September is National Suicide Prevention Month.

In honor of Suicide Prevention Month grab a jacket and come on over to the Madison Cares HOPE Garden at 60 West Main on Thursdays in September. We will have locks, rocks and painting supplies available. Supplies will be out 11AM-4:30 PM. Write what gives you hope or brings you happiness on a lock and paint a rock to share your hope.

1 in 5 people struggle with mental illness.
1 person every 16.2 minutes dies by suicide in the United States and Globally every 40 seconds.
Suicide and mental illness effect all genders, races and classes of people.
If you are struggling know you are not alone and there is hope and help.
Suicide Prevention Life Line 1-800-273-8255
*If you are calling/texting from Idaho refer to 208-398-HELP (4357)

By eight the kids were washed,

When memories of homework,

New notebooks, too,
New teachers, new friends
Their anxiety grew.
The parents just giggled,
When they learned of this fright,
And shouted, "Upstairs!

The Madison Operational Levy has passed with 63 percent in favor of renewal

Thank you to everyone who voted in this election.

We recognize, thank and appreciate you trusting us with your hard earned tax dollars. We take our fiscal responsibility very seriously and are grateful for your continued support.

As a district, we have never faced the types of problems and challenges we are currently up against. While these levy dollars will help immensely, the amazing staff, teachers, parents and community standing with and supporting us through these unprecedented times is what we are most grateful for.

As we get ready to start the 2020-2021 school year, some online, some in person and some both, we want to say thank you for trusting us each day with your most prized possessions, your children.

#wearemadison #madisonstrong #backtoschool #thankyou

Why should you take Mental Health First Aid?

Most of us would know how to help if we saw someone having a heart attack—we’d start CPR, or at the very least, call 9-1-1. But too few of us would know how to respond if we saw someone having a panic attack or if we were concerned that a friend or co-worker might be suicidal.

Mental Health First Aid takes the fear and hesitation out of starting conversations about mental health and improving understanding and providing an action plan that teaches people to safely and responsibly identify and address a potential mental illness.

Madison Cares offers free Mental Health First Aid Trainings for anyone 18 years of age and older to attend.

Upcoming classes:
-Youth Mental Health First Aid, Wednesday & Thursday August, 12 & 13, 9:00am-1:00pm *Taught by Rick Croft and Kirk Mace

-Adult Mental Health First Aid, Monday & Tuesday, August 17 & 18, 9:00am-1:00pm *Taught by Travis Schwab

Never have we been so excited to see a school year end. Having a last day of school without students in the building is something we never thought we would experience.

These last four months have been hard, for all of us! We have stretched, done things that are unfamiliar and maybe even uncomfortable. But, we have all stuck together.

Our appreciation for our students, their parents and our wonderful teachers and staff has never been so great. Our appreciation for a community that unites in crisis and works together has never been so great.

So, as we close this school year and launch into the summer (and hopefully less stressful times), we want to thank you for being #madisonstrong.

We thank you for being patient.

We thank you for trusting us as we made hard decisions.
Thank you for working with us as we navigated unchartered waters.

Have a wonderful summer! Stay safe! And we look forward to having your kids back IN OUR SCHOOLS come August. #wearemadison

In last nights Board meeting, they voted to "Waive" Senior projects, all SBAC testing and the Board approved a new grading system which comprises A / B / P / I grades.

Under this new rubric, a teacher may assign an A or B grade for those students who have been earnest and diligent in completing their studies online.

The P grades stands for "Pass" which means a student has done acceptable (or enough) work which provides credit for the class but does not positively or negatively impact their GPA.

An I grade stands for "Incomplete" and this means a student did not complete a sufficient amount of work and they will be provided an opportunity to finish the assigned work in the future.

With all of the no tech, low tech, no, or low bandwidth our homes are facing, we feel it is not appropriate to assign low or failing grades to students.

Given the unprecedented circumstances of our environment, our teachers have been encouraged to be patient and flexible in providing make up time for those students receiving an I grade.

Join us tomorrow to raise awareness for child abuse prevention month by wearing blue!
